newsitem.title: UK: UK bank lending rises 1.040 bln stg in April - BBA.
newsitem.headline: UK bank lending rises 1.040 bln stg in April - BBA.

text.p: Total sterling lending by major British banking groups to the private sector rose a seasonally adjusted 1.040 billion stg in April, the British Bankers Association said on Wednesday.
That was well below the 5.157 billion stg increase seen in March and the underlying six monthly average of about 2.8 billion stg.
The BBA said April's figure incorporated a decline of some 1.3 billion stg by way of reverse repos.
But individuals increased their borrowing by 1.232 billion stg, up from 1.046 billion in March.

"There was no slowing in the momentum of the major banks' lending to persons in April," said Tim Sweeney, the BBA's director general. "In fact, at 1.2 billion, this was the second largest monthly rise since the series began."
The BBA said mortgage lending rose by 740 million stg in April, virtually flat with March and close to the recent monthly average of 728 million.
Consumer credit climbed by 497 million stg, with credit cards responsible for 127 million of that -- well up on March's "relatively weak" 311 million increase.
"Consumer credit recovered very strongly," Sweeney said.
Lending to the financial sector showed a marked rise, up 968 million pounds, but that was well down on the record 1.708 billion rise seen in March.
Notable increases were recorded by leasing companies, securities dealers and insurance and pension funds.
Lending to the manufacturing sector was little changed but there were significant rises for property compenaies and "other retail distribution."

"Elsewhere, demand for finance was fairly muted, in part due to a market decline in gilt repo activity," Sweeney said. "Therefore, overall, the major banks' lending showed only a modest rise, in contrast to the record figure in March."
